resources: MedGuidelines Child-Pugh Score A-drop Colorectal cancer TNM classification (UICC 8th) Acute tonsillitis/pharyngitis algorithm Search < 2 2–3 > 3 > 3.5 2.8–3.5 < 2.8 < 1.7 1.7–2.3 > 2.3 absent slight moderate none grade 1–2 grade 3–4 Age: Male >= 70, Female >= 75 BUN > 21 mg/dL or dehydration SpO2 < 90% or PaO2 < 60 mmHg" Consciousness disorder Systolic pressure < 90 mmHg" Bilirubin (mg/dL) Serum total bilirubin Albumin (g/dL) Albumin (g/dL) Prothrombin (INR) Prothrombin (INR) Ascites Ascites Encephalopathy grade Grade 1: Trivial lack of awareness, Euphoria or anxiety, Shortened attention span, Impairment of addition or subtraction, Altered sleep rhythm. \nGrade 2: Lethargy or apathy, Disorientation for time, Obvious personality change, Inappropriate behavior, Dyspraxia, Asterixis. \nGrade 3: Somnolence to semistupor, Responsive to stimuli, Confused, Gross disorientation, Bizarre behavior. \nGrade 4: Coma Mild, outpatient care Moderate, outpatient or hospital care Severe, hospital care Most severe, ICU admission T factor N factor M factor Tis T1 T2 T3 T4a T4b N0 N1a N1b N1c N2a N2b M0 M1a M1b M1c Tis: intramucosal\nT1: submucosa\nT2: muscularis propria\nT3: pericolorectal\nT4a: perforate visceral peritoneum\nT4b: invade or adherent to adjacent organs or structure. N1a: 1, N1b: 2–3 regional nodes, N1c: Tumour deposit(s), i.e. satellites,* in the subserosa, or in non‐peritonealised pericolic or perirectal soft tissue without regional lymph node metastatic disease\nN2a: 4–6, N2b: 7 or more regional nodes. M1a: one organ without peritoneal metastases\nM1b: more than one organ\nM1c: to the peritoneum with or without other organ involvement. Presence Absence < 38°C ≥ 38°C Temperature >38°C Cough Swollen, tender anterior cervical nodes Tonsillar swelling or exudate 3–14 years 15–44 years ≥45 years Age Airway obstruction Difficulty swallowing/drooling Muffled speech Severe respiratory distress Sepsis None Red flag Follow up Bacterial antigen or culture test Antibiotics (AMPC) Hospital care Need specialist examination Yes No Blood Gas Analysis pH pO2 (mmHg) pCO2 (mmHg) HCO3 (mEq/L) Na+ (mEq/L) Cl- (mEq/L) K+ (mEq/L) Acidemia Alkalemia Metabolic Acidosis Additional respiratory alkalosis Additional respiratory acidosis Albumin Normal anion gap High anion gap Urine Na Urine K Urine Cl Renal tubular acidosis Diarrhea, Sodium infusion, Proximal RTA Lactate, Keto acids, Toxic alcohols Respiratory acidosis Acute respiratory acidosis Additional metabolic acidosis Chronic respiratory acidosis Additional metabolic alkalosis Age Hypoventilation without intrinsic lung disease Hypoventilation with intrinsic lung disease, ventilation–perfusion mismatch, or both Acute respiratory alkalosis Chronic respiratory alkalosis Metabolic Alkalosis Respiratory alkalosis Metabolic alkalosis and respiratory acidosis Metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis Physiological Approach to Assessment of Acid–Base Disturbances\nN Engl J Med 2014;371:1434-45. https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMra1003327
